title: How to Drill Pocket Holes

methods.name: Choosing the Right Drill Bit and Settings

steps.headline: Install a stepped bit onto your drill.
steps.description: Stepped drill bits have a narrower tip and a wider base so a screw can easily slide into the hole it makes. Loosen the chuck, the area where the bit is held, by spinning it counter-clockwise. Slide your stepped bit into place and tighten the chuck by turning it clockwise. Stepped bits can be purchased at your local hardware store.

steps.headline: Charge your drill’s battery completely if it’s wireless.
steps.description: In order to make a clean pocket hole, your drill needs its full charge to get up to speed. Plug your drill battery into the charging base and let it sit until the charging light turns green. When the battery is full, plug it back into your drill. If you have a corded drill, you can skip this step. Drills without a full charge don’t spin at a consistent speed and make it more difficult to make a clean hole in the wood.Tip: Keep a spare drill battery in case you need to charge one while working on a large job.

steps.headline: Set your drill to the fastest speed setting.
steps.description: Many drills usually come with 2-3 different speed settings. Turn the dial or switch on your drill that adjusts the speed until it shows the highest number. Higher speeds will leave your pocket holes with a clean edge rather than a rough one.

steps.headline: Secure the jig to your work station.
steps.description: Pocket hole jigs have holes in the base so you can easily screw them into your work surface. Place a screw in each of the holes and use an electric screwdriver to secure the jig to your table. If you don’t want to damage your work surface by screwing in the jig, secure the back of it to the edge of the table using a hand clamp. Pocket hole jigs can be purchased from your local hardware store or online.

steps.headline: Set the height of the jig to match the thickness of the board.
steps.description: Look at the top of your jig for the slide with measurements written on it. Pull the stopper out next to slide so you can adjust the height of the jig to the thickness of the wood you’re drilling into. Once you set the height, place the stopper back in to secure it. Double check the wood’s actual thickness since it may vary from board to board.

steps.headline: Adjust the collar on the drill bit so the end is ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) off the jig.
steps.description: The collar is a band of metal that comes on each stepped drill bit so you don’t drill too far through the wood. Use a hex wrench to loosen the bolt on the collar and slide it towards the drill. Slide the drill bit through one of the guide holes until it’s ⁄8 in (0.32 cm) from the bottom of the jig. Tighten the collar in place so it doesn’t move.

steps.headline: Clamp the wooden board into the jig.
steps.description: Set the end of the wood you’re drilling in the jig so it’s flush against the slide with the guide holes. Push the clamp on the other side of the jig so it holds the wood in place against the guide. Locate the lever on the front of the job and pull it down so the clamp grasps the wood firmly in place. If your jig doesn’t have a clamp on it, then use a hand clamp to hold the board in place.

steps.headline: Place your drill bit in one of the guide holes on the jig.
steps.description: Use one of the guide holes that’s ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) from the edge of your board. Slide the stepped bit into the guide until it’s about halfway in, but not so it’s touching the wood. Some jigs may have more than 2 guide holes. Use the 2 holes that are closest to the edges of your wood.

steps.headline: Push the drill into the wood while it’s spinning at full speed.
steps.description: Squeeze the trigger on your drill until it’s spinning at its fastest speed. As soon as the drill is running, use 2 hands to slowly push the bit through the wood. Keep pushing the bit through the guide hole until the collar is flush with the guide hole. Make sure the drill stays straight while you’re drilling into the wood or else your pocket hole could look messy.Tip: Don't force the drill through the wood when you push it. This could damage the wood or shatter the drill bit.

steps.headline: Run the drill until you pull it out of the jig.
steps.description: Keep pulling the trigger of the drill until you remove your drill from the guide. As soon as the bit is out from the guide, release the trigger and let the drill slow to a stop.

steps.headline: Use the other guide hole to make a second pocket hole.
steps.description: Go to the hole closest to the other side of your wood, and feed the drill bit into the guide. Pull the trigger and push the drill through the wood until the collar stops it. Pull the drill back out before releasing the trigger. Make sure the drill is up to full speed before making your second hole. Always use at least 2 pocket holes to make your joint. Otherwise, the wood could spin once it’s connected to another piece.

steps.headline: Clamp the wood to your work surface.
steps.description: Place the clamp about 1 foot (30 cm) from the area where you plan on drilling so it’s not in the way. Tighten the clamp so the wood is held against your work surface and doesn’t move.

steps.headline: Mark the angle of the hole on the edge of your board.
steps.description: Measure about 1 ⁄2 inches (3.8 cm) from the end of your board and make a line to mark where to start your holes. Turn the board onto its edge and draw a 45-degree angle from the line to the other side of your board. Flip the board over and repeat the process on the other side. Use a speed square to help draw the angle if you need to.

steps.headline: Hold the drill so the bit is perpendicular to the wood.
steps.description: Set the drill bit on your board about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the edge. Hold the drill handle with your dominant hand and keep the top of the drill straight with your non-dominant hand. Make sure the bit is pointing straight down into the wood.

steps.headline: Drill ⁄4–⁄2 in (0.64–1.27 cm) straight into the wood.
steps.description: Squeeze the trigger completely on your drill so it’s running at the fastest speed. Slowly press into the wood, using your non-dominant hand to guide the drill straight down. Only drill into the wood’s surface by about ⁄4–⁄2 in (0.64–1.27 cm). Don’t put too much pressure on the drill when you push down or else you could break the bit.

steps.headline: Tilt your drill bit while it’s running to match the angle you drew.
steps.description:
Once you’ve drilled down ⁄4–⁄2 in (0.64–1.27 cm), start tilting your drill backward until it matches the angle you drew on the side. Make sure to keep the drill running so it cuts into the wood at the angle. Keep pushing the drill through the wood until just the tip breaks through the other side. Don’t push the drill bit completely through the wood or else the screw won’t stay secure later on. Using Standard Drill Bits
First, drill completely through the wood with a bit matching the thickness of your screws. Then use a drill bit the same width as the screws' heads in the same spot, but only drill three-quarters of the way through.
